abstracts.cdata!:
This Third Poverty Reduction Support
            Credit (PRSCIII) Project seeks to implement Vietnam's
            Comprehensive Poverty Reduction and Growth Strategy (CPRGS),
            and, provides further support to Vietnam's reform
            program. The project shall strengthen the reform program on
            several fronts: 1) promotion of greater internal and
            external competition, to endorse an acceleration in the
            divestiture of State-owned enterprises (SOEs) and
            State-owned commercial banks (SOCBs). Additionally it aims
            at improving transparency and accountability in SOE
            operations, and in the banking sector, while supporting the
            establishment of a sound regulatory framework for policy
            lending by the Government. These measures should improve the
            allocation of resources, economic growth and job creation.
            2) The project will also promote human development, through
            an expanded budget appropriation, and higher quality
            standards for education, through resources for health care
            costs of the poor, and through mechanisms to complete the
            transfer of land-use rights to households, especially in
            upland and ethnic minority areas. Further measures will
            improve environmental and water resources management. 3) In
            an effort to build modern governance, increased transparency
            and accountability of public finances, simplified
            administrative procedures, and steps towards curbing
            corruption will be pursued. Other actions aim at revamping
            planning processes, moving towards the alignment of
            policies, and resources to attain well-specified development
            goals. However risks include financial aspects, and
            governance practices, particularly as it regards the
            incomplete structural reform, which could jeopardize growth
            and stability in the long term. Also, the introduction of
            market forces in the social sectors, and decentralization
            are pressing service delivery, leading to increased
            inequality, with a less inclusive growth. And, there is a
            fiduciary risk associated with this project, if inadequate
            progress on budget transparency occurs; however, the
            Government recently embarked in an anti-corruption strategy.
